posts.name: Bethiel
posts.cooked:
I wish there would be the ability to choose to block some or all contacts from sending me a voice message. For example:

  • nobody may send voice messages to me
  • select contacts who may or may not send voice messages to me
  • everybody may send voice messages to me

If somebody is blocked from sending me voice messages I would prefer that the sender gets notified like “the recipient does not want receive voice messages”

thank you

link_counts.title: Generate text transcript of voice notes
Block video/image from a selected user

posts.cooked:
1. What is use case for this request?
  2. Should Signal also prevent sending video/audio attachment? Because user can voice record in some OS application and send you a video/audio attachment.

posts.name: Bethiel
posts.cooked:
The use case is to notify the sender that the recipient does not want to receive voice messages and the sender should write a text message.

Many users hate receiving voice messages (as reply) or are not able to listen to them. The same does not explicitly apply to video attachments which could be watched without audio.
Couldn’t you just ask your contact not to send you voice messages?
Simple solution: tell your contact that you do not wish (or are unable) to listen to voice notes and ask them to resend their message as text.

posts.name: A Nascimento
posts.cooked:
Good ideia!

My phone, my rules. No audio message.

posts.name: Tobias
posts.cooked:
I don’t like voice messages at all, in conversations I usually write text, so I can find messages with ease using the search option.

But in some groups and personal conversations some members annoy the team with voice messages that I cannot prevent.

Please implement a toggle to stop that, per conversation and per group.
Or maybe a toggle "Each user is allowed to send one single voice message [per hour | per day | per week | at all].

Thanks!

posts.name: Quirin F. Schroll
posts.cooked:
Apparently, back when it didn’t, I wasn’t the only one who considered it to be a feature that Signal had no voice messages. In all my life, I received 1 (one) voice message that I accepted being one. Any other was just laziness on part of the sender.

Please implement this. Someone should make a study on how many people send voice messages and how many hate them.

posts.name: Salt
posts.cooked:
Herohtar:

Simple solution: tell your contact that you do not wish (or are unable) to listen to voice notes and ask them to resend their message as text.

@Bolpat I don’t see the issue with this. This is a problem that lies within the sender or the recipient, not Signal.

posts.name: Jeremy
posts.cooked: This is akin to making cars only do right turns in a country where you drive in the right lane. Use it or don’t.

Please let us opt-out from voice messages!

What is “tell your contact” for a solution? I don’t want discussions with contacts, I simply don’t want to receive any message as voice.
In case of (video) calls you can simply decline but why should you not be asked if you want to receive voice messages?

For groups:

  • Let admins be able to turn them off
  • If voice messages are active and a member turned them off display a small information that not every one receives voice messages

That should solve most possible issues.

I’m a supporter and Signal fan, now also here for this request!

P.S.: If you’re not able to receive there is no need to be able to send ofc. Same procedure like read-status e.g.

posts.name: Salt
posts.cooked:
Seven-Sails-Raider:

I simply don’t want to receive any message as voice.

May I ask why? I do understand that voice messages can be a hassle sometimes. However, if I’m in a situation where I can’t listen to one, I tell the sender that I can’t listen to it and they usually write out the message.

First things that com to my mind:

That procedure would be unnecessary if you got it as written msg first. While recording a msg may be a bit more convenient for the sender a text message is more efficient as it’s always readable and it’s not senselessly stuffing your backup with MBs of data rather than (K)Bs.

IMHO it’s retrogressive to hold a phone to your head if it’s not a call but just one recorded message. And I also don’t like listening to those with speakers on at all as I tend to have people around at work and at home.

Not sure why it’s necessary to explain the demand if it’s there already.

posts.name: Salt
posts.cooked:
Seven-Sails-Raider:

Not sure why it’s necessary to explain the demand if it’s there already.

Really I’m just trying to better understand the feature request.

Seven-Sails-Raider:

IMHO it’s retrogressive to hold a phone to your head if it’s not a call but just one recorded message. And I also don’t like listening to those with speakers on at all as I tend to have people around at work and at home.

I completely understand this and have dealt with this in the past.

EDIT: However, I don’t think blocking voice messages entirely is necessarily the best way to go about making this better.

Salt:

EDIT: However, I don’t think blocking voice messages entirely is necessarily the best way to go about making this better.

In 2 years of Signal there was no moment when I wanted to (be able to) receive a voice message.

posts.name: Salt
posts.cooked:
Seven-Sails-Raider:

In 2 years of Signal there was no moment when I wanted to (be able to) receive a voice message.

That’s a fair point. But, and this is a genuine question, why not just ask your contacts to refrain from sending you voice messages? It seems to me, if you tell them you don’t like voice message and won’t listen to them, then they’d be forced to write out the messages.

I think if Signal implemented a way to completely block voice messages it would cause a lot of compatibility headaches.

Seven-Sails-Raider:

and it’s not senselessly stuffing your backup with MBs of data rather than (K)Bs.

I wonder if messing around with media auto-download settings could keep your Signal app from auto-downloading voice messages.

posts.name: Jeremy
posts.cooked:
Seven-Sails-Raider:

That procedure would be unnecessary if you got it as written msg first. While recording a msg may be a bit more convenient for the sender a text message is more efficient as it’s always readable and it’s not senselessly stuffing your backup with MBs of data rather than (K)Bs.

I don’t use them often, but sometimes it’s easier to shoot a question to my spouse if I’m in the store and typing takes too long for a simple thing.

Seven-Sails-Raider:

Not sure why it’s necessary to explain the demand if it’s there already.

Because it’s asynchronous…like voicemail, which is a staple of communication via phone.

jeremymasters:

Because it’s asynchronous…like voicemail, which is a staple of communication via phone.

Well there we are, the first thing I disable when I get a new SIM card There are people who can live completely without it, believe it or not.
And in this case the opt-out has been there like always.

An alternative I could live with (but not sure about the privacy topic): speech-to-text

Sorry, missed this post of yours somehow.

Salt:

That’s a fair point. But, and this is a genuine question, why not just ask your contacts to refrain from sending you voice messages? It seems to me, if you tell them you don’t like voice message and won’t listen to them, then they’d be forced to write out the messages.

Can’t imagine it’s convenient for someone who uses those a lot to remember which people like it or not.

Salt:

I think if Signal implemented a way to completely block voice messages it would cause a lot of compatibility headaches.

Don’t think so as I already mentioned here

Salt:

I wonder if messing around with media auto-download settings could keep your Signal app from auto-downloading voice messages.

Or you just can’t receive any and this is no issue
I send voice messages all the time if I’m stopped at a red light in the car. It’s a lot safer than texting.
